I’ve been living with PTSD for 10 years now and just when I thought things were getting better I had a trigger event while travelling on public transport and now I’m left to face these demons again. I’m 25 now and barely a functioning adult. It sucks, it takes away all your energy. The thing about addiction being a coping mechanism for trauma is that it’s not just substance abuse. I’ve always been cautious about substance abuse and I’ve been sober all my life but my addiction is based on approval from others. I constantly need to be validated and liked by others which ultimately resulted into a cell phone addiction. The thing about growth is that it has to be reinforced daily, you can’t just go to a therapy session and expect magic to happen. My experience of being a corporate trainer is that the human psyche tends to gravitate back to its original state and default settings. Taking a workshop will only have short term results. If you really want to change your toxic patterns, you have to reinforce the change every single day and stick to it till it becomes your default setting.

As someone who lives and is treated for PTSD, this is very accurate. Great video! Childhood neglect, abuse and then a emotionally abusive relationship with a partner ending cracked me and brought to the surface a lot of repressed childhood memories and the fact I was coping by binge drinking (I did not realize it was not normal due to an alcoholic parent growing up)
I have been doing EMDR which helps immensely, eating properly, exercise, having limits for how much and when I drink, taking a light anti-anxiety medication. I feel right as rain and have a flourishing successful career, people who love me and am in control! :) No one can tell I have had any trauma unless I choose to tell them. DON'T give up hope of having your life back <3

Yeah, everybody thinks shellshock & PTSD are the same. George Carlin talked about it. But no, it is a bit different. WWI vets who were in the trenches, particularly at the battle of Somme, experienced the constant shelling/explosions for days and days on end, with no real hearing protection. This constant stressors on the hearing and mind resulted in "shell shock".
Go ahead and look this up. Check more recent sources than some from 20ish+ years ago.

I also can sometimes be put into a sour mood when something specific related to an event that has happened to me occurs again and unfortunately it's made a lot of the more positive views on life seem foolish because I've been in situations where had I not had that demeanor going in, it would've been for the better. I think DID can derive heavily or even solely on PTSD. When having multiple personality disorders, it can be extremely effective in coping with trauma from the past. When a personality takes over, you do not have to deal with your current situation. You dissociate because your brain knows you cannot handle this trauma, especially if it is a repeated trauma. Maybe you're too young to handle it at the time so another personality, supernatural, inanimate object, or animal alter takes over and handles it for you. I'm saying this from personal experience from someone very close to me and from others who have this disorder and shared their stories online. And from researching, I found that PTSD can also be a huge factor as to why a person would want to change their gender. Hear me out, I am also open to the belief that someone is born trans aka they grew up knowing they were born in the wrong body. BUT! I want to also share what I've learned from others. A lot of people who are reportedly trans and regret their transition have said that they were sexually abused in their childhood, therefore believing that if they changed their gender, they could have stopped what happened to them, or that it would rid their disgust and guilt from the past (the body they were born in may disgust them because of that horrible event). They thought that if were born the opposite gender, they wouldn't have been violated. I was violated in my childhood as well (biologically I am female) and I had trouble with my own gender growing up. Now I refer to myself as gender fluid, but there was a point in time where I wanted to be male and nothing else. I think those who think the same and have gone through similar situations should think deeply about what they think will make them feel better so that they don't feel worse later on. I'm so sad that so many people can relate to such atrocities, but it's important to talk about so we can help others. We have to learn as much as we can and teach the youth so we can protect them from these dangers.

I see some people self-diagnosed themselves with PTSD. According to DSM-V diagnosis of PTSD requires a "Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence [...]". In this case traumatic event is meant to be objective. Symptoms of PTSD appears after some time after the event: from two weeks to decades, but mostly about a month (this differs PTSD and ASD, Accute Stress Disorder).

My point is: you probably don't have PTSD if you haven't been in situation where you or someone else was physically threatened. There is a lot of hurtful events that may broke metnal healthiness, but they won't result in PTSD.

It's not a pure categorial difference - a proper diagnose is key to a successful treatment. Psychiatric syndroms are not amusement, like horoscopes. When you are dysfunctional or suffering through condition of your mind you should have go to a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist, not making your own diagnose.

In 2015, I was at my mom's house. She went to the bathroom (Looking back on it now, she might have gone to do heroin; the nurse at the hospital said she had heroin in her) and didn't come back for 15+ minutes. I have no damn clue why I didn't check on her sooner than I did, but eventually, I went to the bathroom door and knocked. There was no response, so I opened the door. My mom was unconscious, hunched over the sink, with no pulse or breath, ice cold. I went and called 911. The lady on the phone told me to try and get my mom onto the floor and attempt CPR. I couldn't get her off the sink, she felt too heavy. The 911 operator told me that paramedics were on the way, so I hung up. I went into the living room and just sat down and cried. It felt like I was sitting there for hours. Eventually, the paramedics came and got a very, very weak pulse out of her. They got my mom to a hospital, and when my grandparents and I got there, they said that my mom was in a coma and would most likely never wake up. They said that if for some reason she did wake up, she would be in a vegetative state. A day or two later, my family decided to pull the plug on her. Not a day goes by where I don't think about my mom, and I'm always reliving that day and thinking of things I could have done to save her. Since then, whenever people talk about the heroin epidemic, I break down and cry and shake and I can't stop. To the people who are reading this, if you know someone who is addicted to drugs, please try and get them to stop. I wouldn't want anybody to go through what I did and am. R.I.P. Amanda Ciupek.

Those of us who knew and understood the story of Tolkein and his struggle with PTSD remain the few that are saddened by the fact that the penultimate chapter of The Return of the King titled "The Scouring of the Shire" was left out of the movie considering that that one chapter, more than any other, truly capture what Tolkein was trying to convey with regards to his own personal struggle. In that chapter, Frodo and company return to the shire to see it taken over by Saruman and Wormtongue. The hobbits, now hardened by war, rally the locals to save The Shire. This chapter talks at length about how Frodo, Sam, Merry and Pippin are all seen as different by everyone else because of what they have seen. They also are unable to discuss what went on in the time they were gone fighting the great war because none of the locals would possibly understand. That entire chapter was an allegory of Tolkein himself and how isolated he was when he returned, with nobody to possibly talk to that would understand all of the horrible things that he had to endure. It puts Frodo's mysterious journey to the Gray Havens at the end of the book in a much different context.

One can never "go back" - whether an individual is traumatized or not. the real question is 'how to move forward' when one feels rooted by the events of the trauma(s).

Also, symptoms of trauma do not "fade". That is a fallacy. The primary symptom of trauma is an inability to bridge information from what 'was known' to 'what became known', but in a particular way which has the direct consequence of conflict (and therefore 'pain') within the subject (as not all 'surprises' are traumatic). There is a profound difference between a 'lesser trauma' (which is nevertheless impactful) of a peer calling you a bad name during recess at school, and for example, being beaten - or sent to war. In 'time' (and the conscious development of life experience) one may be able to confront past traumas of 'name calling from peers' and provide the aforementioned 'bridge' so that the incident is no longer at odds with one's 'expectations of the world' (according to society's definitions). But in the case of participating in a war when all societal standards are null and void, the process to reconcile or to 'bridge' this real and perceived gap is slow and often arduous. "Fade", indeed!

0:35 - 0:37: "His novels were the byproduct of trauma" is incorrect. A "byproduct" is a secondary product". In this case, the effects of the trauma are a "byproduct" from the experience itself. The novels were created after years of processing (accepting, 'debriefing', reconciling, etc) the effects of the 'initial series of traumas', thereby making the novels a 'tertiary product'. Do not equate "trauma" with 'ability to create art or any other form of inherent or metaphorical means of self expression. Trauma is debilitating. Creativity is a sign of healing.

This video was really helpful. As someone who deals with PTSD and substance abuse, I can tell you that it's definitely a combination of genetics and trauma that produced my alcoholism.

I recently had a DNA test from GeneSight, to help my doctors know what medications my liver can and can't process. Turns out I have a genetic mutation that not only ruled out a whole class of medications, but is also highly correlated with alcoholism. So, there's that genetic component that's been passed on through the generations.

And you were right on the money when you talked about the debate between it being a biological drive or an obsession of the mind. It's something that's been debated since AA got started, back in 1935. The conclusion back then was that it was both, and based on my experience, I agree with that.

Like I said, genetically, I'm set up to be an alcoholic, but I didn't trigger the disease of alcoholism until I had that first drink. But that first drink also sparks an obsession in my mind, where I can never stop with just one. With PTSD, and the numbness and misery that comes with it, it's hard to turn down anything that makes you feel good for a change. The pleasurable effect is just too strong.

I agree that both need to be treated concurrently. I tried therapy before I got sober, but I didn't get anything out of it because I was still drinking. It wasn't until I entered recovery that I could start making the changes that therapy encourages.

I'm about to start EMDR therapy, and my therapist explained the science behind it. She talked about how trauma increases the size of the amygdala, which is part of the reason people become sensitive to triggers. Then, with each subsequent trauma or depression, the hippo-campus gets smaller. So, like you said, those memories aren't being filed away into long-term memory, which means that the intensity of the experience is relived, over and over again. It's the difference between "This sucks" and "That sucked" - like it's a clogged pipe.

She said that there's nothing we can currently do to decrease the size of the amygdala, but EMDR therapy does increase the size of the hippo-campus. By doing EMDR, the traumatic memories can get properly filed away, which decreases the sensitivity to triggers and flashbacks. I have great hope in this, because ugh, PTSD suuuuucks.

Powerful NON-allegorical stories.  As Tolkien specifically said, there are no allegories in his novels. Addressing his own trauma allowed him to also help thousands of other people address their traumas.

My thoughts as a Tolkien scholar first and a psychologist second:  Tolkien didn't write allegory, but his writing was informed by his life experiences.  Frodo often acts like a soldier going through trauma because that's something Tolkien was familiar with, but none of the specifics (ie the One Ring, etc) can be tied down as symbols for concrete real-world things.  They can perform similar functions, but it's not allegory.  For example, Frodo's PTSD-like symptoms are results of his contact with the ring and his struggles through darkness, but the ring isn't Tolkien's way of making a statement about a particular element of the war or anything.  Parts of his stories mirror real-world structures because they are deeply human, and explore human issues withing their own framework.  If you want a true coercive allegory, read The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe.

Going to point out that PTSD is not the only trauma disorder out there, merely the most well understood. I was diagnosed with something called 'van der Kolk syndrome', more commonly known as Developmental Trauma Disorder, a largely unknown disorder but one both related to and distinct from PTSD. Whereas PTSD arises from relatively short, very acute trauma, DTD comes about from chronic, low levels of trauma that aren't usually seen to be traumatic (social isolation is a very good example of such an instance), but does have a very pervasive, insidious influence on one's self (indeed, it's 'developmental' trauma because it badly and continually damages how that person develops over time). It's important to be aware that one can suffer trauma and not be aware of the seriousness of the damage done. Those single, parsed instances of pain that we try to construct our emotional narrative out of might appear trite if we haven't suffered war or rape or an abusive parent, but that doesn't change that pain can still exist, and can be debilitating. Worse still, not recognising pain as pain means it is never treated, and support is never received. Sometimes, no matter how petty the trigger, it really isn't whining.

I was diagnosed with emotional unstable disorder (also know as borderline) and went through a type of therapy known as DBT (dialectical behavior therapy). In this diagnosis both PTSD and addiction is common, though it wasn't my problem. This type of therapy starts with trying to stop the destructive behaviour - can be addiction, self harm, disordered eating, suicidal ideation etc, and once you're not dependent on that any more (because for people with this diagnosis it our only way we know how to cope with difficult emotion and situations) you can start dealing with what's underneath - and for many that is the trauma that you've experienced. And it's done in that order so you don't fall into the destructive behaviors once again, when you start opening up about the emotional wounds.

This doesn't have much to do with the topic of this episode, but I would like to ask my fellow Tolkien-Fans: Do you really think The Lord of the Rings is a product of positive post-traumatic growth? The connection between Tolkien's work and his war experience is obvious, but isn't it more of an example of escapism - Tolkien trying to recreate the world he lost in the trenches?
In the end, the War of the Ring is a pretty simple, archaic conflict of Good vs Evil, the good side fighting with honour and having a just and noble aim. Unlike WWI, where you can't pick any participating country as "the bad guys" and where horrible weapons were used by every side - a war that was also, unlike the War of the Ring, ultimately pointless. And the peaceful Shire was inspired by rural England in Tolkien's childhood days. Of course, Tolkien created ambiguous characters, like Boromir, Saruman, Denethor, Gollum and Frodo. But all in all, it looks like Tolkien tried to make sense of what he witnessed by ascribing everything evil to one side - and then letting the good side win.
I'm not sure about this interpretation, though. What do you think?

Another coping mechanism for dealing with trauma/abuse (both in the moment and post-trauma) is compulsive fantasizing/"maladaptive daydreaming". To dissociate from trauma (especially in childhood), some people will fantasize that they are in a different situation. This can be addictive and the person may carry on doing this for the rest of their life as there is no treatment for it yet. Many who suffer from it have not suffered any trauma, the same way not all alcoholics have PTSD, but they may do so because they are not content with their lives or they have social anxiety. Some people spend vast amounts of their time in a fantasy world of their own making, even though they know it is not real, and this can cause great disruption to their lives and make them very sad and frustrated. Many people who have it have speculated that JRR Tolkien may have had this, as the rich fantasy world he created mirrors the complex fantasies often created by those who suffer from MD. There has been very little research on this and it has so far been neglected by the psychological community, but there are about 3 good studies on it and real life evidence on the WildMinds support forum if anyone is interested.

I love this crash course psychology series but I work in alcohol dependence research and I have some beef with the episode. First off, I feel like you missed a lot of opportunities to talk about treatments other than traditional 12-step programs. Programs like AA are not suitable for everyone and for those who are alcohol dependent going completely sober without going through medical detox is life-threatening. There are many other harm-reduction treatments - mostly outside of the US - that have much higher success rates (depending on how you define "success"). I'm not saying 12-step problems don't work - they do for many - but it is not the only method of "curing" addiction. Further, there is also the "social" view of addiction which isn't a mental illness or a physical disease, but rather more of a learned behavior model. I've glad you bring up the idea of dual diagnoses; one of the most important thing I've learned from our studies is that most people will tell you they don't have a problem with alcohol, they have a problem with the underlying trauma. Also to note: alcohol is a drug and it grinds my gears when people say "drugs and alcohol." Overall super informative and on point! :)

What I find interesting is that LOTR is an inherently conservative book/movie. Think about it: The people of Numenor (Aragorn) are of an older, nobler stock, long-living and pure of heart. The elves embody permanence, but also a value set that is conditioned on that (they love starlight, for example. can you say "eternal" 3 times without thinking about an elv?). Aragorn is long aquainted before he marries, he even does so only after the father has implicitly given him permission (Elrond brings him the new sword) by siding with him in the war. As far as I can tell, there was no premarital "relations".
This is interesting because JRR Tolkien chose to write conservatively - and what is conservatism but a yearning for a solid foundation, good morals, values, permanence, etc.? It is conceivable that Tolkien was influenced by his trauma to yearn for those things and he either sunconsciously used them or constructed the story consciously to promote these concepts. Strange. In this context is seems negative and positive have the meaning that's inherently a value judgement of good and bad respectively. But when it comes to psychotic disorders, positive and negative have the meaning simply or present and absent, respectively. The reason why I think physiology has a reputation as being a soft science as opposed to hard is due largely to subjective criteria. For example, maladaptive (part of the criteria for a disorder) is largely dependent on circumstance. Is that obsession maladaptive if it's your livelihood to make the thing you're obsessed with? Is it also to be under the delusion that stepping on a crack will in fact break your momma's back, yet not to believe in the existence of an all-powerful sky god? These are the questions.
